base_methods.evidence_text: Incorporating syntactic dependency structure with graph convolutional networks (GCNs) has shown advantages, but performance depends on dependency parsers.

compared_methods.comparison_result: DualGCN model consistently outperforms attention-based and syntax-based methods
compared_methods.evidence_text: The DualGCN model consistently outperforms attention-based and syntax-based methods on Restaurant14, Laptop14 and Twitter datasets.
DualGCN model outperforms SynGCN-head on the Restaurant14 and Laptop14 datasets

compared_methods.comparison_result: DualGCN + BERT and DualGCN + BERT-PT show improved performance over the basic DualGCN model and other BERT-based methods
compared_methods.evidence_text: DualGCN + BERT and DualGCN + BERT-PT show improved performance over the basic DualGCN model and other BERT-based methods.

datasets_used.dataset_description: All datasets have three sentimental polarities: positive, neutral, and negative
datasets_used.evidence_text: The first group includes Restaurant14, Laptop14, and Twitter.

stated_contributions: integration of syntactic knowledge through SynGCN and semantic information through SemGCN
stated_advantages: captures both syntactic knowledge and semantic information

acknowledged_limitations: dependency parsing results can be inaccurate
GCNs may not perform well on datasets insensitive to syntactic dependency
failure_cases: The SynGCN model fails in capturing the representation of key words in complex sentences
